user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketSendTo:
```c
int32 OS_SocketSendTo(osal_id_t sock_id, const void *buffer, size_t buflen, const OS_SockAddr_t *RemoteAddr)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(buflen);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(RemoteAddr);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        if (stream->socket_type != OS_SocketType_DATAGRAM)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketSendTo_Impl(&token, buffer, buflen, RemoteAddr);
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (stream->socket_type != OS_SocketType_DATAGRAM)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The fragment only reads stream->socket_type; Rule 8.13 concerns pointer declarations that should be const-qualified when possible. From this code alone there is no evidence the object is only read everywhere — the pointer may be intentionally non-const for other uses. (If, in the wider code, stream is never used to modify the object, then the declaration should be changed to const OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream and that would be a violation as currently written.)
